description: Borrowed from Afrikaans smous or Dutch smous, from a Yiddish word whose precise origin is uncertain. One theory is that it derives from Yiddish משה‎ (moyshe, “Moses”), pronounced moushe in Western Yiddish, from Hebrew מֹשֶׁה‎ (moshé, “Moses”).

entries.meaning: (chiefly South Africa, historical) A Jew from Germany or Eastern Europe.

verbs.description: smous (third-person singular simple present smouses, present participle smousing, simple past and past participle smoused)

entries.meaning: (South Africa, historical) To go about selling goods, as an itinerant peddler.
examples: Not only South Africans, White and Black, but fortune hunters from Europe and America, Indian and Chinese labourers and traders, and Jews from the ghettoes (sic) and shtetles of Eastern Europe, who had come to 'smous'  […]
